laws.summary: Ohio does not have a statewide law prohibiting employers from asking applicants about salary history.
requirements: Employers may legally ask about prior salary
Use of salary history may increase risk under federal anti-discrimination laws
Best practice is to avoid salary history inquiries to reduce bias risk
laws.notes: Many employers voluntarily avoid salary history questions for pay equity reasons.

laws.summary: Ohio does not require employers to disclose wage ranges in job postings or offer letters.
laws.statute_citation: No current Ohio statute mandating pay transparency
requirements: Wage range disclosure is not legally required
Employers may voluntarily disclose pay information
Federal equal pay and anti-discrimination laws still apply
laws.notes: Multi-state employers may still choose to include pay ranges for consistency.

laws.summary: Non-compete agreements are generally enforceable in Ohio if reasonable in duration, geography, and scope.
laws.statute_citation: Ohio common law (e.g., Raimonde v. Van Vlerah, 42 Ohio St.2d 21)
requirements: Must protect a legitimate business interest
Must be reasonable in time duration
Must be reasonable in geographic scope
Must not impose undue hardship on employee
Courts may modify overly broad restrictions rather than void them entirely
laws.notes: Ohio courts commonly apply a balancing test and may rewrite overbroad clauses.

laws.summary: Ohio does not have a statewide ban-the-box law for private employers, but federal FCRA requirements apply when using third-party background check vendors.
laws.statute_citation: Fair Credit Reporting Act (15 U.S.C. ยง 1681)
requirements: Written consent required before third-party background checks
Must provide pre-adverse action notice before taking negative action
Must provide copy of report and summary of rights
Must issue final adverse action notice if decision is finalized
Criminal history must be used in a non-discriminatory manner
laws.notes: FCRA compliance is mandatory whenever a consumer reporting agency is used.

laws.summary: Ohio does not mandate paid sick leave statewide but protects certain civic leave rights.
laws.statute_citation: Ohio Rev. Code ยง 2313.19 (jury duty); ยง 3501.02 (voting leave)
requirements: Employers must allow employees to attend jury duty without retaliation
Employees must be allowed reasonable time off to vote if schedule conflicts with polling hours
No statewide paid sick leave requirement
laws.notes: Offer letters should not conflict with statutory civic leave protections.

laws.summary: Ohio permits workplace drug testing and does not provide employment protections for recreational cannabis use.
laws.statute_citation: Ohio Rev. Code Title 37; Ohio employment law guidance
requirements: Employers may maintain drug-free workplace policies
Employers may discipline or refuse to hire based on positive drug tests
Recreational cannabis use is not protected in employment
Policies should be applied consistently
laws.notes: Ohio is employer-friendly regarding drug testing policies.

laws.summary: Arbitration agreements are generally enforceable in Ohio if consistent with contract law and federal arbitration principles.
laws.statute_citation: Federal Arbitration Act; Ohio Revised Code Chapter 2711
requirements: Agreement must be clear and voluntary
Must not be unconscionable
Must provide reasonable notice
Courts may invalidate overly one-sided clauses
laws.notes: Fair drafting is important for enforceability.

laws.summary: Ohio follows the at-will employment doctrine, subject to statutory, contractual, and public policy exceptions.
requirements: Employment is presumed at-will unless contract specifies otherwise
Cannot terminate for discriminatory reasons
Cannot retaliate for protected activity
Public policy exceptions apply
Employee handbooks may create implied contractual obligations
laws.notes: Clear at-will language in offer letters is recommended.

laws.summary: Ohio law prohibits employment discrimination on protected characteristics similar to federal law.
laws.statute_citation: Ohio Civil Rights Act (Ohio Rev. Code ยง 4112)
requirements: Cannot discriminate based on race, color, religion, sex, national origin
Cannot discriminate based on disability
Cannot discriminate based on age (40+)
Harassment is prohibited
Retaliation for protected activity is prohibited
laws.notes: Offer letters must avoid language implying exclusion or bias.

data_quality.sources: Ohio Revised Code, Ohio Department of Commerce, Ohio Civil Rights Commission, official state guidance
data_quality.coverage_completeness: comprehensive for offer-letter and hiring compliance

additional_notes.general_guidance: Ohio is generally employer-friendly, with few state-specific hiring restrictions beyond federal law, but non-competes must be reasonable and anti-discrimination and FCRA compliance are critical.
recent_developments: No statewide pay transparency law enacted as of 2026
No statewide paid sick leave mandate
Continued reliance on common law for non-competes
